awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Remote Characterization of Microbial Mats in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, through In Situ Sampling and Spectral Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial mats are found throughout the McMurdo Dry Valleys where summer snowmelt provides liquid water that allows these mats to flourish. Researchers have long studied the environmental conditions microbial mats need to grow. Despite these efforts, it has been difficult to develop a broad picture of these unique ecosystems. Recent advances in satellite technology now provide researchers an exciting new tool to study these special Antarctic ecosystems from space using the unique spectral signatures associated with microbial mats. This new technology not only offers the promise that microbial mats can be mapped and studied from space, this research will also help protect these delicate environments from potentially harmful human impacts that can occur when studying them from the ground. This project will use satellite imagery and spectroscopic techniques to identify and map microbial mat communities and relate their properties and distributions to both field and lab-based measurements. This research provides an exciting new tool to help document and understand the distribution of a major component of the Antarctic ecosystem in the McMurdo Dry Valleys.

The goal of this project is to establish quantitative relationships between spectral signatures derived from orbit and the physiological status and biogeochemical properties of microbial mat communities in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, as measured by field and laboratory analyses on collected samples. The goal wioll be met by (1) refining atmospheric correction techniques using in situ radiometric rectification to derive accurate surface spectra; (2) collecting multispectral orbital images concurrent with in situ sampling and spectral measurements in the field to ensure temporal comparability; (3) measuring sediment, water, and microbial mat samples for organic and inorganic carbon content, essential biogeochemical nutrients, and chlorophyll-a to determine relevant mat characteristics; and (4) quantitatively associating these laboratory-derived characteristics with field-derived and orbital spectral signatures and parameters.  The result of this work will be a more robust quantitative link between the distribution of microbial mat communities and their biogeochemical properties to landscape-scale spectral signatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

# 1744785. COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Remote Characterization of Microbial Mats in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, through In Situ Sampling and Spectral Validation

Report Submission Period: 08/01/2019 to 07/31/2020

The goal of this project was to establish quantitative relationships between spectral signatures derived from orbit and the physiological status and biogeochemical properties of microbial mat communities in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, as measured by field and laboratory analyses on collected samples. This project will address this goal by (1) refining atmospheric correction techniques using in situ radiometric rectification to derive accurate surface spectra; (2) collecting multispectral orbital images concurrent with in situ sampling and spectral measurements in the field to ensure temporal comparability; (3) measuring sediment, water, and microbial mat samples for organic and inorganic carbon content, essential biogeochemical nutrients, and chlorophyll-a to determine key mat characteristics; and (4) quantitatively associating these laboratory-derived characteristics with field-derived and orbital spectral signatures and parameters. The result of this work will be the first quantitative link between the distribution of microbial mat communities, their health, and their biogeochemical properties to landscape-scale spectral signatures.

We published a manuscript associating remotely acquired spectral signatures with different ecological properties (Salvatore et al. 2020, Antarctic Science). This work confirms that quantitative associations between surface properties and VNIR reflectance spectra can be determined remotely. This work also set the stage for additional remote sensing investigations that make use of spectral data for identifying and/or modeling ecological properties, including Power et al. (2020, Polar Biology) and Salvatore et al. (in press, International Journal of Remote Sensing). In Power et al. (2020, Polar Biology), Virginia Tech graduate student Sarah Power associated remote sensing signatures with critical biological properties in black microbial mats in Canada Stream. Salvatore et al. (in press, International Journal of Remote Sensing) shows how linear unmixing models and our spectral endmember library can be used to quantify biomass from the observed spectral signatures. This work then goes on to estimate total photosynthetically active biomass in the Fryxell basin using remote sensing data, with the results predicting more than one million kilograms of carbon present.

Co-PI Sokol demonstrated how this work provides a link between the distribution of microbial mat communities, their health, and landscape-scale spectral signatures by using maps of cyanobacterial mat distributions in a modeling study to assess alternative hypotheses about the mechanisms that maintain the biodiversity of the diatoms that reside in these mats (Sokol et al. 2020, ﻿Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution). Specifically, metacommunity simulations were constrained using maps of cyanobacterial mats derived from remote imagery, and models were informed by long-term data of cyanobacterial mat properties (including chlorophyll-a and resident diatom community composition) from the McMurdo LTER program. Outcomes from this study demonstrated the importance of spatially explicit landscape scale measurements of mat distributions, and how they can be used to inform our understanding of the dynamics that maintain biodiversity in the Dry Valleys.

Our four stated objectives have all been accomplished, and we are currently finalizing our efforts to complete Objective #4 (quantitatively associate lab-derived characteristics with field-derived and orbital spectral signatures and parameters). While Power et al. (2020, ﻿Polar Biology﻿) and Salvatore et al. (2020, ﻿Antarctic Science﻿) and (in press, ﻿International Journal of Remote Sensing﻿) correlated spectral signatures to biomass estimates, we are still investigating the correlation between spectral signatures and specific pigment abundances and assemblages. This work is being led by graduate students Sarah Power (Virginia Tech) and Schuyler Borges (NAU) along with Co-I Stanish. The complexity of pigment assemblages and the combination of compositional and physical properties that lead to the resultant spectral signatures is challenging, but we are confident that this final avenue of investigation will help us to understand the full capabilities of remote sensing data in the investigation of photosynthetic microbial and bryophyte ecosystems.
